nodes.text: Settler mortality during European colonization influenced whether colonists settled or created extractive institutions, and those institutions causally affect long-run income per capita
Europeans adopted different colonization policies that produced distinct institutional types: settler colonies with pro-property-rights institutions and extractive colonies with weak property rights
The feasibility of European settlement was largely determined by the disease/mortality environment faced by Europeans
Colonial institutions tended to persist after independence and form the basis of current institutions
Method: Use historical European settler mortality rates as an instrument for current institutions to estimate causal effect of institutions on income (two-stage least squares IV approach)
Method / Data: Mortality data come from records of soldiers, bishops, and sailors (Curtin and other historical sources) and were used to construct potential settler mortality per location

Evidence (reduced form): There is a strong negative relationship between historical settler mortality and present-day GDP per capita across ex-colonies (higher settler mortality associated with lower current income)

Evidence (first stage): Log settler mortality explains a substantial share of cross-country variation in current institutions (about 25â€“30 percent in main specifications) and predicts lower institutional quality where mortality was high

Result (2SLS): Instrumenting institutions with settler mortality yields a large, statistically significant estimate of the effect of institutions on log income per capita (IV coefficients roughly order one), larger than OLS estimates

Evidence (robustness): IV estimates are robust to excluding Neo-Europes or Africa, and to adding controls for latitude, colonizer identity, legal origin, religion, climate, natural resources, soil quality, ethnolinguistic fragmentation, current disease measures, and fraction of European descent

Evidence (overidentification and alternate instruments): Overidentification tests using settlements and early institutions as additional instruments and using a yellow-fever exposure instrument provide no evidence that settler mortality directly affects income other than via institutions

Conclusion: Institutional differences originating in colonial-era settlement decisions explain a large part of long-run cross-country income differences; once institutions are accounted for, geographic indicators (e.g., distance from equator, Africa dummy) lose explanatory power

Limitation / Assumption: Identification relies on the exclusion restriction that historical settler mortality affects current income only through institutions; potential measurement error in institution variables and the impossibility of controlling for all omitted factors are acknowledged
